comment: So sorry to hear this. "Tharki", a common hindi team to describe, h*rny, desperate, is what most men are. They feel a sense of entitlement to do anything, especially when they get some alcohol in their system. Unfortunately, you see this a lot from the less literate people who haven't been exposed to the world (not like there aren't educated predators). It's more the fascination of seeing a white person in the flesh that they've been seeing online. It's like giving a baby a new toy, so they want to explore it. I do not suggest any person travelling alone, unless you are a seasoned one and have the grit to handle the sh*t that comes your way. I'm Indian and my white wife (then girlfriend) backpacked North-South India in 2016 for over 3 months and trust me it wasn't easy navigating it, but we had the best time ever exploring this beautiful country and diverse culture. In my experience, the people in the South are more receptive and civilized than North India - just because they've had more exposure. I would strongly recommend visiting India but do take necessary precautions, good planning and would only recommend a group tour through a reputed organization, one that has a good social media following with proof and reviews. comment:
Mujhe Dubai me ek incident yaad hai. Humare family ke just peeche aur ek Indian group tha. Normal line tha, Burj ke lift se neeche utarne ke liye. Boht dur tak line tha, kafi obvious tha ki log ek ke bad ek samne jayenge. Humlog thori der dhyan nhi de rhe the achanak uncle mujhe cross karke samne jaane wale the with his group. Mai boli ap kaha ja rhe hai humlog hai. Matlab line ka kuch lihaaz nhi hai kichu nhi hai. Unko lagta hai samne jane me thora gap kya hua to wo samne aise hi line cut kar sakte hai. To wo piche ja hi rhe the to unko samne se koi bulaya ye bolke ki humare sathe hai. Wo wahi excuse ab mujhe deke samne chale gaye.

Line zigzag shape me ja rha tha. To isliye do line the Jo lift ke pas the- ek tha ek corner jaha U turn murke phir u turn leke last lift pe charne wala line aa rha tha. (Samajhna thora muskil hai, picture nhi ha) To wo uncle and unke helper wale ka jo bara group tha wo log soche ki wo u turn line hi last line hai, next unhi logo ko waha se charne denge. Airport check in jaisa line ka concept kaise samajh nhi aya idk, lekin wo log wahi khare rehe. Notice hi nhi kiye ki age jana hai. Normally waise situation me we tell people ki age chaliye. I said nothing, bas aise hi cross karke line me age nikal gye. Phir unlog ko samajh aya ki line dusre jaga se khulta ha . Piche se clearly sunai par rha tha bol rhe hai koi baat nhi etc etc. Humlog jab lift me charhe uske bhi 1 ya times bad charhe honge wo group ke log.

Basic decency Boht kam hai yaha ke logo me. I was very sad ki aise behaviour se humlog ko represent kar rhe hai foreign jagah me. Kitne sare desh ke log the, sab ka normal civics sense wala behaviour tha. And humare desh ke logo ko waha bhi line katna, grouping karna normal laga. Agar wo request karte, if I'm not in a hurry, mai aise hi allow kar deti hu logo ko. Mujhe bura laga tha ki aise behaviour se mai associated hu, in whatever way  Anyways, humlog sirf khud ko hi represent kar sakte hai. Baki log kya kare hum par nhi hai. Bas accha encourage hi kar sakte hai. Desh ko zaleel jo hona tha aise hi ho rhe hai

I am sorry for the issues faced by this traveler ,Unfortunately people some times goes to very poor areas and oldest and shady parts of the cities and then generalize for the whole country , which is not an accurate assessment, as far as convenience is concerned now  in india we have Apps and websites to get any service at the click of a button, any service like bus, train, hotel, airlines, food, restaurant, intercity transport all can be done online, even in terms of digital transactions india did 43 billion digital transactions in 2021 alone , you won't need cash for transactions in most parts of the urban areas. but people don't want to do any research and some blame also falls on our travel tourism authorities to not inform travelers no proper signage etc.
If you look india from my perspective it is one of the oldest civilizations in the world, India is a mosaic of multicultural experiences. With a rich heritage and myriad attractions, the country is among the most popular tourist destinations in the world. It covers an area of 32, 87,263 sq. km, extending from the snow-covered Himalayan heights to the tropical rain forests of the south, which give the country a distinct geographical entity.
Fringed by the Great Himalayas in the north, it stretches southwards and at the Tropic of Cancer, tapers off into the Indian Ocean between the Bay of Bengal on the east and the Arabian Sea on the west. 
India has 2400 KMs of himalayan mountain ranges, 7500 KM of coastline with some average , but some beautiful and stunning beaches , india has around 13000 islands , it has a Desert(Thar) and the  place with most rainfall in the world is also in india(Assam), it has a number of huge national park and wild life sanctuaries with rare animals and species which includes the majestic Royal Bengal Tiger, Asiatic lions , Rhino's, elephants , bears etc. Different types of flora and fauna , it has gift of spectacular ancient architecture with thousand of years old temples and cities , also upcoming  modern architecture, India's infrastructure is growing at a scale which is highest in the world , 27 cities now have metro trains or work in progress .with the highest GDP growth among major economies, india is transforming rapidly
As you travel the expanse of the country, you are greeted by diverse nuances of cuisines, faiths, arts, crafts, music, nature, lands, tribes, history and adventure sports. India has a mesmeric conflation of the old and the new. As the bustling old bazaars rub shoulders with swanky shopping malls, and majestic monuments accompany luxurious heritage hotels, the quintessential traveller can get the best of both worlds. Head to the mountains, enjoy a beach retreat or cruise through the golden Thar, India has options galore for all.

comment: Thanks for the honest video. On the personal questions issue I should say sometimes even we Indians find some of the queries uncomfortable. But as a rule the standards for a question being personal are somewhat different from the West. India is a family centric society, so asking questions about one's family is deemed quite normal (wanting to see your sister's photo is definitely not). If I bring a friend of mine, Indian or not, the very first questions they are gonna face are like "What's your name?", "What's your father's name?", "What does he do?", " Does your mom work also?", " Who else are there in your family?" and the like. Even, at times people may feel ignored if not asked such questions after being acquainted for the first time. Here 'living with parents' does not have the disapproving stigma attached to it. Rather, it's the opposite, it's what expected of good, grown-up and caring and responsible children.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, now you're telling me that asking about my family is totally fine, but I can't ask you about yours? Sounds fair to me. Gotta respect your cultural norms now. Nice

comment:
I live in India. The trash problem is very frustrating. People have(in general) very less awareness of what they are doing. Public cleanliness is not a part of life for many people. It won't be wrong to say that people are lazy in that regard as many people won't bother to go to throw garbage in the bin even if it is 10 steps away. They just throw it right there on the ground and sometimes in water too. At many places,there's no garbage collection system and hence people are forced to do it. So, government needs to work on that. But what I've noticed traveling around India is that there will be places where you'd not see a piece of trash and you'll find parts of the country very filthy. North is more polluted than the South. West isn't really great when it comes to cleanliness. Northeast is better in that regard. The government has been pushing Swachha Bharat (clean India) mission rigorously through awareness, advertising and all. It has yielded good results but there is a very long way to go. 
I feel cleanliness is a habit. If it becomes a habit, it won't go away.
The other cons you mentioned are also largely true. I relate to them as someone who lives here.

comment: I am really sorry for "cons" that you have faced. But I think I should point to few of the things. India is a diverse country in every aspect. 1.3 Billion people. And yes plan your journey properly, you will get app for home delivery of everything, from communication, food, vegetables, medicine etc. Buy train tickets reserved or unreserved from app. Please do not mind, but I have to say this that if you are not on a very tight budget then please book at least AC second class. comment:
I will try to give my pov on each cons:
Garbage issue: this is going to take a fundamental change in the mentally of the ppl, but I also think authorities haven't done enough to curb this problem, there is no proper waste management system esp in smaller towns and cities, also they need to lay down strict rules and hv heavy fines on culprits, things will change. Same ppl when go to foreign countries follow these rules and don't throw litter outside.
Scams and cons: because of the sheer no. Of ppl here, the no. Of such will always be higher, but I think in % they are low, most of us will always try and help you out.
Stray animals: well this is a cultural thing, can't judge anything keeping Western lenses, like many Indians will find keeping animals in fences and chains is regressive and that they shd be free to roam.
Personal space and selfies: I just don't understand the obsession re selfies with foreigners, nut in general if personal space is your thing then this country is not for you. We are very social ppl and it's very common to ask questions like what does my parents do, what do I do for living, I'm married or not. But asking for a pic of your sister is very very weird, even for us. So stay away from such ppl without worrying whether you looking like rude, if you feel awkward, just ignore, don't pay attention.
SIM cards and train tickets: again the govt and authorities needs to do more for tourism and make these things easy. Though I have watched some vlogs in which ppl hv said it's very easy to get SIM cards at airport and that irctc website accepts international cards, do check vlogs by Ivana Perkovic or Christine Kaaloa.

In general, India is very diverse country, in one city itself you will find many different kind of ppl. For e.g. in Pune where I live, You will find the cleanest of areas where ppl won't bother you with selfies, ppl displaying pda, girls wearing anything they want and then in other areas you will also find the things you mentioned. It's just up to ppl what they are seeking here and truth of this country is a mix of all these things.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, you're gonna be that tourist who gets offended by everything. Welcome to India, where every rule is made to be broken and every rule-breaker is treated like a saint. Good luck

comment: Uttar Pradesh and Bihar are the most underdeveloped, populated, less literate states of India. I have been to at least 15 states in India. In India, Uttar Pradesh ( Agra) and Bihar are the dirtiest states. Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab are lot cleaner. North East India Sikkim, Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh etc are cleaner than North India. Overall South Indian states like Goa, Kerala, Tamil Nadu are much cleaner and people are literate.  In major cities like Delhi, New Delhi is clean and green but Old Delhi is dirty and sketchy. In Mumbai, South Mumbai is cleaner but suburbs are not clean. I  think you are generalising and exaggerating things.  You said people throw garbage in the river. Actually it's not a garbage but flowers and Garlands which they throw. Especially in Temple towns like Varanasi. After Prime Minister Modi launched Clean India Mission the Sanitation coverage in India is over 98%. Overall people have been made aware of cleaneliness. People in major cities have started segregating dry and wet waste.  I would say the older generation was illierate and way dirtier. The current generation is more cleaner and literate.  So it will take another twenty years or a generation more for India to be a cleaner country. As India gets Richer, the government will have more money for waste management but it's the mindset of Indians which needs to be changed.   Cheers from Mumbai
counterspeech_english: Oh great, so now I'm just making stuff up? Nice to know your "facts" are based on a few trips to a couple cities. Shame on you for spreading such nonsense. Cheers.

comment:
You will see India how you want to see it.
Many tourists from G7 countries go along the Golden Triangle because it is replete with monuments, forts, palaces, temples and 17th century bazaars. Many tourists from these countries are hopping from monument to monument with smart English-speaking guides.
Tourists from Russia are only interested in Goa, this is because they look for places with warm climate, warm waters, affordability, easy availability of alcohol and relaxed dress codes. Goa seems to fulfill those categories.
Tourists from Israel, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Malayasia are interested in visiting Shimla, Manali and Dharmasala. Some have even travelled to Gulmarg and Pahalgam. This is because these places have cold weather and are the cheapest places for them to experience snowfall.
Students from Iraq, Iran and African countries visit Pune and Bangalore.
Finally Bangladeshi tourists are only interested in shopping malls of Kolkata and in drinking.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, now I have to justify why my country isn't special. Way to go, insightful analysis. Let's hear more about why I'm so inferior to other nations. Nice one! ï¿½

comment:
1) Best transportation to use in India is metro. India has the 8th largest metro system in the world. Currently, metro operates in 15 major cities of India.
2) Except Uber, India also has Ola app for travelling.
3) Indian people don't depend on using cards or atm much as we have unified payment interface (UPI) system which allows us to pay/transfer money directly through the mobile.
4) India is very safe, just avoid going to shady places, cheap hotels and avoid Old Delhi type of places at all cost.
5) India's food is very rich with spices and street foods are made with loads of spices which a foreigner's stomach is not used to. I would suggest to avoid street food as much as possible. Better to go to hotels and restaurants.

comment:
Don't you mean the South being vegetarian vs North being non vegetarian?  Udipi style cuisine, in the South, is pure vegetarian...look for a town named Udipi/Udupi.  That's my heritage...what my parents grew up eating...and I like. It's part of me. North is more of Mughlai meat curries. Mumbai is seafood baby...all the way!!!...not to mention Parsi style also....Parsi as in Freddie Mercury (Farokh Bulsara) and Parsi. Goa is very heavily Portuguese influence in food and in religion and architecture. 

Also the trains are what made India.  Maybe it's because my tata (grandfather) was a railway inspector on Western Railways in Mumbai, along with many Uncles working in the railways. 

Additionally, you glanced right over the Deccan and Bangalore, Mysore, Coimbatore, and Ooty. Maybe for me, it's because of family. Bangalore is the third city that makes up the economic "locomotive" of India. Bangalore reminds my of California at the elevation of Denver. While Bangalore is a bit overbuilt, Mysore is beautiful...if you like palaces, yoga retreats, and studying culture and religion. Many beautiful outdoor parks also. 

FYI I happen to like the meter gauge railroad trip from Coimbatore to Ooty... actually have to switch trains in between, to connect to meter gauge train going up the mountain....and you can see them engage the cogwheel going up the grading to the Niligiri tea plantation areas around Ooty. 

BTW, between Delhi and Mumbai, if you have the time, take the Mumbai Rajdhani Express Train instead of the airplane.  It's and experience... particularly in AC first class sleeper car..... nothing like Amtrak. You can also take the Gharib Rath Express Train. 

Also, the Southernmost point of mainland India on Cape Comorin lies a hamlet called Ashramam in Kanyakumari District of Tamil Nadu (Kerala border). That is my father's native place as they call it in India (place where my father's family originates from)... beautiful place where the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal meet.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, another one of those "I know everything about India" posts. Except you got the whole thing wrong. The South isn't vegetarian, just has fewer cows. And Mumbai doesn't eat

comment: I went to India too! I was born in India but I came to America when I was really young. Anyway I didn't really remember it much, I didn't remember anything actually haha I just know what there is to know about my religion, Hinduism, my parents have taught me all they know but I didn't really get to experience the live culture until this past summer. I went to India after 13 years, and my reactions were exactly the same as yours. I went to north and south India. In the north I stayed mainly in Lucknow and New Delhi, then in south India I went to Chennai. I also went to Lumbini, Nepal, where Buddha was born. I saw the Indian and Nepal border. I visited my extended family after like 13 years. Even though I didn't have memories with them it was very easy to get along and enjoy because blood is just blood, I am also fluent in Hindi so that made everything easier. My first few days sucked but I got used to their lifestyle. I don't look Indian, somehow cuz I'm 100% Indian, but yeah people were ripping me off as well. I was also surprised seeing dogs everywhere, I felt so bad but that's just how it is in India lol there are cute homeless dogs everywhere. You brought back so many amazing memories from my trip to India! I miss it like crazy, I was there for one month and it was the best experience of my life. I learned so much and I traveled, met new people, saw different lifestyles, experienced my culture and religion, it was just an amazing experience and I came to realize multiple things, one being seeing how privileged we really are in America. No tp didn't take long to get used it, their version is way cleaner lol. The electricity went on and off. Haha anyway street shopping is awesome in India, because everything is so cheap. There are no slumps, shit-holes, ghettos or poor uneducated hungry people in any corner of India. Each and every Indian is well educated, dead honest, equally wealthy and prosperous. Its democratic government is immensely effective, totally clean and corruption-free -- as proven by zero unemployment consistently for decades. Its police force holds the reputation of having the highest global standards of integrity, is very clean, corruption-free, humane, competent and professional in their jobs - they don't take bribes or beat ordinary citizens brutally on the streets with batons or long rods like what you usually see in bollywood movies. Its judiciary system has stellar track records where judges had solved and closed all legal cases as quickly as the blink of an eye. Public utilities, public transportation, public education and notably its public toilets are all ranked first in the world. And, in case you're not aware of yet, India proudly has the world largest public toilet freely available for everyone - the Ganga River, where people can conveniently take a bath, pee and poop at the same time in one go. And you should know too that public safety in India is much better than any other countries in the world - very very safe for women to walk alone at night.

comment:
It's amazing how with digitization the image of India is so drastically changing. The western media always portray India as a backward country with no culture. We're in fact the most culturally rich and diverse. We had more money and class than the world could ever imagine, but centuries of invasions and loot changed it. 

And despite all the problems, India is still making it. This decade belongs to India. We're an example of perseverance and sincerity. We need more vloggers like Drew to travel across India, so the world knows who we really are and what we're made of. 

Everytime I see an Indian travel vlog by travellers like Drew - I feel proud.. and appreciative of these vloggers who are here to explore but also end up showing the real picture of the country.

comment:
5 Reasons Why India Is the Dirtiest and the Most Polluted Country in The World

What is the first thing that comes to your mind when you hear India? Most people will answer cows, toilets, Bollywood, the Taj Mahal, and high rape rates.

All these assessments are not wrong, considering that this country, which is located at the South Asian region has more negative sides than positive sides.

India is known as a backward and outdated country. Its social problems are very complex.

Apart from the issue of rape, most parts of India are slums, which impress people from all over the world, that they are filthy and dirty. This is also proven by surveys from various research institutions which place India at the top of the list of the dirtiest countries with the highest levels of pollutants in the world.

5 reasons India is the most polluted country

1. Poverty

India often boasts about its rapid economic development, but a survey by the Rangarajan Committee shows that more than 38% of the population live below the poverty line in 2023.

With great poverty, most residents live in inappropriate places such as riverbanks, slums.

2. Density

India is one of the most densely populated countries in the world with very limited natural resources compared to its booming population. Its population reaches 1.4 billion.

Poverty and density are the 'right' combination to create a slum and polluted environmental situation. Garbage, human waste, animal waste is strewn everywhere on the streets of India, the large number of vehicles and related things certainly make India look so dirty and filthy.

3. Don't care about the surrounding environment

There is an interesting fact from the primitive lifestyle of Indians. They tend not to care about the surrounding environment.
This is because Indians think that public facilities are the responsibility of other people, especially the government. So even though a lot of rubbish has piled up, even though it disturbs the view and causes an unpleasant smell, it's all left alone. Even though outsiders think this is very sad, Indians, whose mindset is backward and uncivilized, have become accustomed to this situation.

4. Caste Mentality

It is common knowledge that Indian society, which is predominantly Hindu, knows caste in their life. Because of these social norms, people who feel they belong to a higher class tend not to want to do work that is identical to that of people from the strata below them.

5. Government Services

India is a very poor country. This results in minimal government services and attention to environmental issues. Such as widening waterways, emptying trash cans and so on.

comment: I am in India as of this comment on a 7-day trip to Delhi. This is my second time in India and I am hungry for more. My first trip back in 2016 was to Mumbai where I spent most of my time in Powai. I was fascinated by the culture, the sights, the nature, and the contrast between old and new parts of the city as well as its rich, middle class, and slum areas. My best memory from the trip was one hell of a hike in the Sanjay Gandhi National Park, which is a recommendation I cannot make enough if you ever find yourself in Mumbai, especially the view from the top, which is surreal to say the least! I just concluded a full day in Agra yesterday and looked at a few monuments and local artisan workshops which was very rich and which I also recommend to anyone coming to Agra in addition to visiting the Taj Mahal, of course. My discovery of the massive land of India is still in its infancy and I look forward to the next trip! The one thing I still cannot get used to is the aggressive driving, be it here in Gurgaon (where I'm staying), in Agra yesterday, or in Powai a few years back! comment:
I backpacked alone as a female traveler for 2 months in India when I was 22 years old. I visited all the mentioned places plus some. It was by far the hardest country to travel in Iâ€™ve ever tried even to this date 13 years later and 70+ countries visited. So many inappropriate comments from men, heckling and Iâ€™ve left hotels/hostels sooner rather than planned due to feeling very unsafe from the male staff. However, I also truly had an amazing trip and do not regret going. I travelled aloned, mainly stained in hostels, planned my own trips and transport which means I never had to deal with â€œguidesâ€ or â€œdriversâ€. Just normal tuktuk and taxi drivers, took the train on the third class (packed with locals with rats running around the floor) and felt completely safe. 

I know I was lucky that nothing too bad happened to me. But to be fair, I met mostly normal people on the street which were very kind. Yes, cat-calling, being followed and offered opium straight up on the street is a strange experience. Would I recommend India for anyone? Absolutely not. For an experienced traveller who is willing to take the risk? Yes, for sure, itâ€™s a stunning country. Would I go back? Nope, too hard and not worth the risk for me any more. I fully recommend going to Nepal, Bhutan or Sri Lanka instead. Felt the most safe in those countries - even more than SE Asian countries.

We rebuffed him, I was helpless to help her, will never forget her steely survival spirit. Otherwise, the trip went OK. Early 1980s I spent 3 months in northern India on a seed buying trip with my boyfriend. I wore a wedding ring and we told people we were married. When I walked around the rural city on my own I had problems. A police officer chatting me up. Pebbles being thrown at me with hissing noises. Why visit a deeply sexist and corrupt country?

comment: As an Indian it surprises me that some folks could be so crazy for a photo with a random white skinned woman. I know what's lacking. It's EMPATHY. It's not a statement generalizing all Indians but it's mostly true in almost all parts of India especially the Northern part - Jammu Kashmir, Haryana, Punjab, Delhi, Uttrakhand, Himachal, Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan to some parts. You need to avoid Bihar and Jharkhand at all costs if you are travelling alone men or women irrespective. Research very carefully before you travel to northern India. The safer places to visit are eastern part of India like Meghalaya, Manipur, Nagaland, Mizoram, Arunachal. People are more empathetic and the system is organized. Southern India is more okayish in terms of travelling solo. There are plenty of places to travel around the world. India is over hyped, there's nothing here except for some natural beauty at some parts of the country. If you are travelling to gather spritual experience then you'd probably be scammed. It's all a sham. God has left this country very long ago.

comment: I am an Indian living in Europe, and I am truly sorry to hear about your experience. I can understand the deep cultural differences at play. I want to help you and others make sense of this issue. In India, white peopleâ€”especially womenâ€”are often seen almost like celebrities, and men sometimes want photos with them, somewhat like paparazzi who hounded Princess Diana. Many female celebrities in the US face similar struggles and mental health challenges, which is very unfortunate, with Dianaâ€™s tragic story being the saddest example. One of my Russian friends in Goa manages this by charging 500 rupees per photo and asking people to form a line, with no touching allowed. This strategy can work in some cases. Traveling solo is a very Western idea, and many parts of India remain culturally centuries behind. That said, I know several white female friends who travel solo here and handle these challenges quite well. I have face similar situation in China when people and school kids wanted to take photos with me and my African friend.

comment: Your first mistake was to book a tour. Travelling independently means you'll be staying at traveller hotels/hostels where you'll be surrounded by other travellers, who on the whole will look out for you. I spent 10 weeks travelling 'solo' in India, but in fact was rarely alone - I constantly met people in my accommodation who were happy to go out sightseeing together, travel together to onward destinations and even share rooms if you trusted them (always women for the room-sharing, obvs!). Being together with other people so much felt pretty safe, and we were rarely targets for groups of men (other than a bit of cat-calling). I had a great time.

comment: I was in India three times in the late 1970s and experienced it all on a much lower scale, harassment from people trying to sell something or Western women occasionally being harassed while seeking company from other Westerners for protection. At that time there were already reports of Dowry murder cases and women who had acid shed on them. Nevertheless, as a Westerner you were not nearly as harassed as is described in today's reports. People were more curious about young travelers from the West and hospitable. But what was already noticeable back then was the extreme, Victorian-like sexual repression of society. Young men asked for porn magazines. There were early reports of ultrasound scans of pregnant women who did not want female babies. There was also a mixture of inferiority complexes and a lack of distance towards people from the West. I think that the Internet, social media and smartphones have exacerbated the situation for Western travelers in recent decades. A strange mix comes together. On the one hand, pride in India's own rapid rise, combined with rising Hindu nationalism and decolonization discussions, an aggressive mix. People see the West in decline and, on the one hand, envy it for its free way of life and at the same time pity it. At the same time, Indian society is still extremely strict on gender issues. Premarital relationships are still undesirable and marriages are extremely expensive. Young men without girlfriends have a hard time making contact with the opposite sex, are extremely uptight and sexually frustrated, consume Western porn and appear in mutually encouraging groups of men who become a danger to single girls and women. In addition, there is still a persistent misogynistic attitude in society. All of this seems to Westerners like an anachronism that they cannot cope with. Our emancipatory movements have led to widespread gender equality and respect for other cultures, accompanied by a decolonial guilty conscience that makes us vulnerable. We do not realize that the Internet, which has no borders, with its porn industry resulting from liberalism, has led to great desire for such freedoms and at the same time to contempt for Western values. Western women are seen as available, which is a huge misconception. Liberal excesses like the porn industry in the West are massively misunderstood as the sexual availability of women to sexually frustrated men. They do not understand the concept of equality and mutual respect between the sexes and western female pride and female self-confidence . The West must be careful that its values are not undermined and must still find a concept to defend these values internationally without instructing other cultures.
counterspeech_english: Oh wow, sounds like your trip to India was just a goldmine of enlightening experiences. Your description is so vivid and detailed, like you were there yesterday. Way to bring back the good old

comment:
I hope this comment doesn't get moderated. First and foremost, I'm sorry you had a terrible experience. I would very much like to know what travel agency you used, cause others, if they choose to go, probably should avoid that travel agency. 

In terms of being sexually harassed online, months after the trip, that is disgusting, and I do condemn it, without exception. 

I would like to say however, that as with any country, travelling is a mixed bag and some have a good and others have a bad experience. Would I suggest travelling to India alone? Probably not. But I would say that for any country. And if I personally would do that, I'd be very careful about potential pitfalls (not casting any aspersions on the breadth of your research). I've had bad experiences on LA & Detroit cause I ended up in the wrong neighborhoods, and most of middle America, cause many people don't want a brown person around. My aunt got her passport stolen in Madrid. All this to say that experiences vary, and can be good or bad, but I'd be careful about generalizing that over a billion people. 

Personally, I've traveled to India with my wife (who's white and American), and she had no issues. This is also partially because I have a good knowledge of the country and it's cities and know what to avoid and when.

It is not difficult to find recent cases (2020 onwards) of heinous acts against women in the US. I don't think anyone would argue that there shouldn't be any travel to the US because of that. comment:
phoebe I am glad that you made it safely back home. It must be a truly traumatic experiences lecherous men lurking all around and feeling helpless in the sea of cold and crude patriarchally toxic men. That said, let me share my experiences of 25 years living in Delhi as a man from the North East of India, from the first day till the day I left even Indians who look different are not free from harassment of all kinds.

This toxic culture against women particularly women tourist is aggravated by the failure of the law enforcement agency. Why I say this? Of all the racially motivated murder, rape, molestation, harassment against North East women, not even one case had been investigated and justice delivered to victims. Prejudice and stereotypes about the North East are used to justify racial abuse and violence. Even Delhi Police in its 2008 guidelines to the North East People echoed this prejudice. Delhi Police guidelines advised North People to not cook and eat 'smelly' North East food. As a result since the last 2-3 decades lumpen elements and goons have picked up a culture of impunity, a conclusion that they can get away with anything done to the North East people in Delhi and other parts of India.

In 2013 a north East youth from Arunachal Pradesh was beaten to death in broad daylight in Amar Colony, South Delhi a place where I stayed as a college student in the early 1990s. Enough was enough, North East people protested and the UPA govt. set up a committee to examine the racial crisis. Before the committee was actually set up, ethnic civil society organisations were invited by the Home Ministry of the governement of India to New Delhi. A friend of mine who worked in a Naga organization in Kohima asked me to write a draft note to be presented to Mr. P. Chidambaram the then Home Minister. 

The draft note had five points but the key idea was 'Joint-Policing' to bridge the cultural gap. Delhi Police simply was understaffed and had little idea about the North East people and their culture. Police complaints by North East people barely made it to the prosecution stage due to the shoddy investigation. The department of SPUNER or (Special Police Unit Delhi Region) emerged from the South Delhi murder case and the draft note I mailed to friend who called back to say that all the five points had been submitted to the minister.

The point being, right thinking people in India need to ask the question whether it is time to have a new law and a special police force to address the harassment of women/tourists, foreigner or non-foreigner and the fallout of this crisis, India as hell-hole for foreign tourist. If the law is seen to be weak and the force lazy, people tend to think they can get away again and again after committing crimes. In the North East people case the law was seen to be weak and lazy. If the govt wants to genuinely ensure India as a safe tourist destination and project positive image globally, the lecherous and toxic lumpen culture must be firmly dealt with.
counterspeech_english: Oh wow, such enlightening insights. Great to see you've had such a profound experience. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have better things to do than listen to your whining about

comment:
As an Indian, I want to express my concern. The reality is, safety is a major issue here  even many Indians feel afraid to step outside alone. There are bad elements around us everywhere, and many families are hesitant to let their loved ones go out alone.

If youâ€™re planning to travel to India, please make sure youâ€™re accompanied by two or more trusted people from different locations not from same location friends, especially in unfamiliar areas. In general, South India is considered safer compared to some parts of North India. People in the South are often more welcoming and protective toward newcomers.

Unfortunately, some regions in North India are known for scams, and not only do they target foreign tourists, but even visitors from South India are often scammed. This is a harsh reality we must acknowledge and work to change.

India has many beautiful and safe places, but travelers must remain cautious and informed. We hope to see the day when safety and hospitality are truly guaranteed for everyone.

comment:
I remember quite vividly one unsettling evening in Jaipur. While my boyfriend had stepped away to fetch us something to eat, I encountered three rather unruly men. They began harassing me, persistently asking where I was staying, who I was with, and, quite absurdly, demanding selfies. They seemed intoxicated and thoroughly inappropriate. I was utterly speechless!! Frozen in disbelief, scanning for my boyfriend amidst the crowd. When I finally spotted him, he gave me a reassuring smile, a subtle gesture to remain calm as he approached with purpose.

Now, do keep in mind, heâ€™s a 6â€™2â€ boxer and wrestler, quite composed, yet no stranger to asserting boundaries. He addressed them with civility, asking them to kindly step back. However, one of them in a moment of misplaced bravado, attempted to place a hand on my shoulder. Thatâ€™s when my boyfriend gently, but firmly, twisted the manâ€™s wrist, just enough to bring him to his senses. The man apologized promptly, while the other two rather sheepishly wandered off and left him behind.

We returned to our seats, though I remained quite anxious for a time, half expecting them to reappear but thankfully, they did not. Let this serve as a gentle yet serious word of advice, always do your research, find a trusted local if necessary, and most certainly, it is highly recommended to bring someone along. Some men, regrettably, behave like ferals when left unchecked.

Sorry for the trauma Sister... I would want to add some points to clarify what I feel might be the reason for some Indian men to behave this way...

First, some Indian men are used to traditional attire and are in a transitionary phase adapting to western outfits... Hopefully the staring will stop once they get accustomed to it and grow up the maturity to see the person beyond skin...

Second, Indian movies and  advertisements should stop objectifying women... Especially should project the true side of foreign women rather than just project them like having too many affairs and not staying in committed relationships which conveys a wrong idea...

Third, Goa is a place known for booze and not sure whether all men will be in right sense after they drink... So better to travel there with caution...

Till these things happen it is advisable to travel with company... Please do visit South India especially Bengaluru, Mysore (Coorg), Kerala, Hyderabad, Chennai, Coimbatore and Madurai... comment: Dear Phoebe, Very Sad and disappointed to hear your experience in India. I was surfing through utube and your videos came up. The first video that I saw was of Mumbai and some comments in that made me see your Overall feedback video of India which you added 9 months ago. This prompted me to see the rest of your videos Delhi, Agra, Jaipur, Udaipur, and Kerala. Except Kerala, the first thing that came to my mind is that you have seriously got mugged and fooled by the travel company. The places that you stayed are seriously not recommended. Even as a Indian I wont go and stay there with my family. There are better travel companies like Thomas Cook, Kesari Travels, MakeMyTrip, RiyaTravels etc and many other good one. Iam not sure if you were running on a restricted budget, but invest in good and premium stays, guides etc. Even some of your guides seems shady. The good hotels have their own travel desks for tourists for sight seeing and they dont take tourists through sensitive areas and own full responsibilities. Iam also confused as to why police and security at these place didn't act. Ofcourse all countries have sensitive places where the tourist should be on guard. I understand that Northern India has a problem with tourism but not all places and people are like that and Yes south India is a world apart. I saw how happy you were in Kerala and your feedback was very good. The stays were very premium hence you had a good experience. Being a solo travelers could be very overwhelming, I resonate that since iam a motorcyclist and travel a lot. But it is very important to make good research before you venture and Yes India could be tricky. Things may not seem as it is in the paper, and yes what happened in Goa is terrible. I am not able to wrap my mind around as to how did you end up in such scenario and what hotel were you staying and which beach you ventured into. Goa is fully hustling and bustling with tourist and iam shocked how did you end up in such areas in Goa. I have made many tourist friends from Goa and my Goan friends run hospitality business there. Definitely theres much to be asked for from the tour company with whom you booked your tours. My insta handle is @shambhoshankara and I have started following you on Instagram. I stay in Europe now and i would be glad if iam of any help to you in your research work next time you visit India. Have a great travel experience and I wish you all great joy travelling across the world. Takecare

comment: Hey Phoebe, I'm so glad I found your channel! This video caught my attention, because I traveled almost your exact itinerary in India in 2015, except in reverse (started in Goa, then Mumbai, then Udaipur, Jaipur, Agra and finally Delhi). Listening to your experience gave me chills. I was traveling in a small group of 3 women and 1 man. It never occurred to me how different that experience might have been had I been alone. Also I should say that half the trip was for a wedding of a friend who lives there, which was incredible and her family's hospitality was above and beyond. That made a big difference for my trip, but when I am asked whether I'd go back, I'm not sure these days. Everything you've said about the relentless selling I did experience 100%. We had some great guides, but after having nearly identical experiences in two cities (being taken to soooo many vendors as part of the tour), we didn't know how to feel. I will say that Udaipur was by far my best experience too, it's a gorgeous city. But mainly I wanted to comment and say just how sorry I am that you were harassed and terrorized by men multiple times. Your story from Goa is downright terrifying. Glad you are safe. I look forward to seeing more of your travels. And thank you for putting this message out there. I think it's very important to be an informed traveler. Thank you!

comment:
As an Indian, this video left me feeling deeply ashamed. I watched and listened with growing horror to this young lady narrate her harrowing ordeal while she was traveling in India. For whatever little it's worth, I want to apologise to this young woman, Phoebe, for her traumatic experience, and since there is nothing I can really do to mitigate the damage caused to her by the scoundrels she encountered on her tour, I thought I might leave a few suggestions for the future.

For all westerners traveling to India, please make note of the following:

1. If you are a woman, never ever be alone even for a second. It doesn't matter how old you are, or whether you are black or white or anything else. The predators don't discriminate when it comes to abuse, harassment and worse.

Always have some men near you who you feel will be there to stand with you in case you get accosted by predators. I'm sorry, I know that sounds misogynistic and patriarchal, but I'm just saying whatever occurs to me in the interests of safety. Your friends don't even have to be men of your own country, they could be men of any nationality, as long as you feel you can genuinely trust them with your safety and well-being.

2. The moment you feel unsafe, immediately pull out your phone and start taking a video of the people troubling you. That alone might be enough to intimidate any would-be harassers. It may or may not be enough, but it's a start, and it's still better than nothing. This one is actually tricky because I'm fully aware that in a frightening situation this would not occur to most people, as they are too shocked and frightened to respond at all, but if you are prepared for it beforehand, it might be easier to remember in times of crisis.

3. If possible, contact your country's embassy and high commission and seek help the moment something bad happens to you. It might also be a good idea to get in touch with the Indian Police, the government, the Ministry of Tourism etc. Record and document all conversations you have with local authorities, with names and designations if possible. They aren't really going to be very helpful, but again, it's still better than nothing at all, and you never know, someone might decide to step up and take action.

4. Making and sharing Youtube videos like this is an excellent idea. That's one reason I'm commenting here, so that it gets a little more reach. This raises awareness about the situation and ensures that similar or worse things don't happen to other people.

5. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT believe that you are overreacting or being unreasonable, or that you might have possibly done something to provoke this behaviour from other people. You are not responsible for how other people are making you feel. This is especially true of women.

6. If possible, name and shame the people who have harassed you. This one is especially important. It will warn others of who exactly to avoid and what to expect in case anyone runs into these people. Don't be embarassed to take the names of people who have troubled you if you know them, name the business and companies that have caused you distress if you can, and feel free to share any photos and videos you have of these people. It would also be an excellent idea to pass on this evidence to local authorities such as the police. Again, this may or may not be of use, but who knows? It's worth trying.

7. Don't let such experiences shake your confidence or self-esteem. It's normal to be upset and frightened and horrified and even traumatised, but if possible, don't let it harm your opinion of yourself and who you are.

That's all I have to say.
counterspeech_english:
Sorry, but you're just telling her to run and hide like a scared rabbit. Maybe you should've been there to protect her instead of complaining later. Grow up, lady. ğŸ˜¡

comment:
Spent 6 months travelling in India in 2007. Mumbai, Udaipur, Jaipur, Jodhpur, Agra, Varanassi, Goa, Kerala. All these things you mentioned happened to me and to a couple of Canadian girls I ended up travelling with that I met in Agra. They were happy to travel with me as a form of protection. They were also followed, hassled and photographed on the beaches by men as well as waking up on sleeper trains with groups of men standing around them watching them sleep!

The sex culture in India is completely warped, along with forced marriages. Men walk around holding hands because holding hands with a woman is a no go. I was also scammed and most people on the street appoching me were always just trying to scam me. I was taken to different hotels than what I asked. 

India is a love/hate relationship for me. Goa is disgusting. You are gettting harrassed 24/7. Women are 5th class citizens and the caste system is very much alive and old barbaric practices still take place. India is a culture shock, mostly because it is so backwards. Stepping over people just lying in the street begging with no limbs. There is so much wrong with this country. People go because they want to see and experience how backwards a society can get. 

I finished by crossing into Nepal after a crazy experience of catching our taxi driver trying to steal stuff out our bags while we were sleeping and still asking for a tip when we arrived at the border!!! Nepal was like stepping onto another planet. People are beautiful and nobody wanted to scam me!

The experience of India is something to behold (to make you realise you glad you are that you weren't born there as a 'lower caste' human and how society has allowed what happens there to go on, even as part of their traditions) but other than that, it's safe to say I would not go back.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, another white savior complex tourist. Glad your trip was so enlightening. Maybe next time you should stick to reading books about India instead of actually experiencing it. Nice one. ï¿½

comment: As a men from europe i travelled 4 months solo across all of india. India is definetly not for beginners. I met solo women travellers who had an amazing time. But they were very experienced travellers. If its your first time india, i can recommend starting your journey in Kolkata. In Kolkata i met 0 scammers, while in Delhi, Agra , Jaipur (golden triangle route.. ) it was a disaster. Also the south of india and himalayas are a lot easier and safer to travel in terms of scammers. India can drain all your energy with all the noise and people, but it gets never boring. Beside the scams in Delhi and rhajastan, i have only good memories about india. You have to get used to see poverty and trash. But if you give india a chance, you can meet amazing friendly people and enjoy some of the best food in the world.

comment: First of all, as Indian we apologize for what you had to experience in India. It should not have happened. There is no explanation or justification of what happened with you. However India is a beautiful country with awesome people. Obviously there are some bad elements in the society but they donâ€™t represent the entire nation. In all my experience living in India, people cannot misbehave with girls in public, as they would face the justice then and there. However I acknowledge we need to have provisions in place to act strictly against those bad elements who cause problems for the tourists and people in general. I am not trying to defend my country but I felt that some of the things that happened with you were very unfortunate and extreme and not very likely to happen in India. I hope and wish that you get to experience better side of Indian/Indians. I hope we eliminate some of the issues that tourists have to face in general and they feel more welcomed. India is all about spirituality, divinity, culture, respect , color, life and celebration and I really wish you experience that someday like many others. Thank you for sharing your story though. comment:
I totally agree that itâ€™s not entirely safe for solo travelers from foreign nations or even Indians themselves, but there are some basic rules of thumb you can follow to avoid more than 90% of such incidents:
1. Avoid booking hotels below $60 per day, as these are often not properly regulated. Given the large number of budget hotels in India due to the population, these cheaper options are usually unfairly managed and more prone to incidents  (we ourselves do not choose to stay at these places). The same applies to restaurants always check reviews on Google before visiting. Aim for restaurants rated $$ or higher on Google Reviews. These options are much less likely to encounter any such issues. Best is to choose well know hotel chains : Leela, Taj, Oberoi, Marriott. For budget travels Zostels are decent as well. Book your hotels online from known websites rather than through a travel guide. 
2. Itâ€™s best, best to just ask an Indian (your neighbor even if you barely know them) in whichever country you are in to help you with the travel. As an Indian, I can say we love to share our culture, and we are just waiting for you to ask us for help with your India travels. You can even ask that colleague/friend/neighbor of yours if they know someone in the cities youâ€™re visiting who can guide you to good places, restaurants, and experiences.
3. Avoid booking through travel websites or tour agencies. This is one of the worst ways to travel in India, as most of these guides, as you mentioned, have commissions tied to specific hotels, restaurants, attractions or literally anywhere they take you to. 
4. Choose cities or areas within cities that are comparatively safer. For example, in my personal opinion (not to say other areas are unsafe), In Mumbai, areas from Bandra to Churchgate/Malabar Hill are the safest, and these are the areas where most of the good restaurants and places to visit are. So, you can book a hotel in any of these areas.
5. Use Uber for cabs, a bunch of other helpful apps like Blinkit (for a 10-15 minute delivery of literally anything even a TV at your place). 

6. Research thoroughly before your trip. If you are traveling with a decent or above-average budget, it will likely be safer and more comfortable than traveling on a tight budget.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, now I need to spend an arm and a leg just to feel safe. Thanks for the tips, traveler. Let's all just enjoy the cheapness of life then, shall we?

comment:
57-year old American male here with three daughters roughly your age. I travel to India often so allow me to share some comments:

First, thank you for your authenticity. Speaking truth is key â€” not just because youâ€™re being of service to others, but youâ€™re moving on from this experience in as healthy a way as possible. You seem brave, and thatâ€™s how you have to be when youâ€™ve had a terrible experience like this. 

Second, make no mistake. You WERE targeted. You were sexually harassed. And you were in very real danger at various moments you described. You did some things right. But if you donâ€™t mind my saying â€” you also did some things quite wrong.  

As you know, India has a well-documented issue with women being treated poorly. Catcalls all the way up to full-on sexual assault. Itâ€™s something I hope you were well aware of before traveling there. The fact that you responded to some of these incidents forcefully (shouting NO, etc) is important. Indian men do understand that and it â€œcanâ€ limit your potential for things getting worse. Good job there. However, there is no way â€” noooo way I would recommend traveling alone as a woman. There is a very real cultural issue in India, and you experienced it first-hand. As you said, itâ€™s not all men.   But as you saw, it only has to be a few men to make the trip perilous for western women traveling alone. And you dealt with a mob at one point. Frighteningly real.

The thing about traveling to India is that you have to have the mental mindset that EVERYTHING may/must change for you at a momentâ€™s notice. You may get sick. You may get hurt. There may be environmental issues like excessive heat or monsoon rains. You have to be ready and willing to make changes immediately, including leaving quickly. I tell people all the time that you have to listen to your gut in India. More than in other places. If youâ€™re not feeling safe â€” youâ€™re very likely not safe.   You have to prepare your brain for this internal conversation BEFORE getting on the airplane. You told yourself positive stories to keep yourself there, while your gut when sending you warning signals. Important ones, too. Truth is, you should have left â€” or radically adjusted your plan â€” as soon as you saw you were the lone traveler on this â€œtour.â€ Forget about the money. Thatâ€™s gone. 

Iâ€™m so glad you arrived back mostly unharmed (sounds like you have some mental healing to go), and that hopefully you have learned a few things about India â€” but also about yourself. Youâ€™re human. You seem a very positive person. And that worked against you here. 

India is a wonderful country filled with amazing people.   But they have their own unique issues just like every other country. India has a "Woman Issue."   You can travel India safely as a woman if you follow strict guidelines, one of which is to NEVER be alone as a western woman traveling extensively like you did. And even though itâ€™s not a relaxing posture, you must have your radar up all the time. I have zero doubt that if you were with a group arranged by a reputable tour, you would have had an amazing time in this incredible place.

I'm sorry this happened to you.  But you've done a good thing posting this video.
counterspeech_english: Wow, thanks for the lecture, but I think you missed the part where I was the one being harassed. Maybe you should have stayed home instead of trying to lecture me. Have fun with your travel

comment:
Sorry you had to go through such situations. I really hope our people behave better.

India is an incredibly diverse country with a population of over 1.4 billion people, so it's important to understand that the experiences of a few may not reflect the reality for all. For many, especially in major cities or tourist spots, foreignersâ€”particularly Westernersâ€”are often treated like celebrities, and the attention they receive can be overwhelming. It's not uncommon for people to approach for photos, follow them around, or act in ways that might seem intrusive.

However, it's essential to remember that this is often more about curiosity and admiration than any malicious intent. India is extremely vast, with every region offering a unique culture, language, and way of life. Things can change drastically from one area to the nextâ€”what might be true in one city may be entirely different just a few hours away. Unlike many other countries, where lifestyles tend to be more similar across the entire nation, India is a place where the culture and pace can shift in the blink of an eye.

With such a massive population and a rich diversity of cultures, regions, and languages, it's important to acknowledge that many people in India may have limited access to education or exposure to global norms. This can sometimes result in a lack of awareness about appropriate behavior or social etiquette, particularly in regard to foreigners or women. The notion of personal space, privacy, and what is considered respectful can vary greatly depending on where you are in India.

That said, understanding India takes more than just a quick  short travelâ€”it requires a deeper engagement with its people and customs. It's important to plan your journey carefully, make friends and acquaintances who can guide you authentically, and always take the time to understand the places you visit by speaking to real locals. India is a land of contrasts and rich diversity, and the more you connect with it on a deeper level, the more rewarding your experience will be.

India can absolutely be safe for women, but like any place in the world, itâ€™s important to be mindful of when, where, and how you navigate. With the right precautions, cultural awareness, and understanding, India offers a rich and rewarding experience for anyone willing to truly engage with its incredible variety and complexity.

It's all about perspective and being prepared. Just like any other country, being informed and taking the right steps can make your travels here comfortable, safe, and memorable.

comment: thereâ€™s a large cultural gap that plays a big role in how interactions between locals and Western tourists are perceived. Many Indians, especially in rural or less urbanized areas, are genuinely curious when they see Western women, not out of malice but because of limited exposure to foreigners. The fascination often leads to requests for photos or awkward interactions that may seem invasive but arenâ€™t meant to be harmful. They just want photos to show to their friends and say, 'I met an American today''. I know it seems belittling for Indians, but actually its really their innocent nature. They see foreigners as someone exotic, alien, from a really advanced society. And Hollywood often portrays them as badass yet nice people. So when they are asking for photos, they are not trying to be harmful. But yes, Scoundrels do exist.

comment:
India is a very tough place to travel around as tourist. I was there for 3 months backpacking when I was about 20 with friends, on the backpacker trail. This was in 1994 though. The sexual harassment aspect was not well publicised at that time and my sister was also travelling around India at the same time. I didn't hear any stories about sexual harassment from anyone at that time. We were well prepared mentally for how tough it was going to be in terms of scams, begging and generally aggressive people trying to get money from you. That said, it was an amazing trip. I liked the South and the North but not so much the middle section. 

The sexual harassment seems to have gotten worse and worse over the years and it seems from your experience that India now has a well deserved reputation for being perhaps the rape capital of the world. 

Can only recommend that single women do not travel there. Even if you go with your boyfriend or male friend, that still may not save you, judging from recent reports. 

So sad that India has become like that.

comment: I have traveled India from the Himalayas to Kaniyakumari for the past 25 years. Mostly I have traveled with groups and friends, and twice by myself. I have witnessed the moral downfall coming little by little. Now is an avalanche, out of control. My worst experiences have been in Agra, Jaipur and Delhi. Mostly scammers and very aggressive men. The state I have felt the most safe is Tamil Nadu. I have never experienced any sort of inappropriate behavior from anyone. Kerala is also quite safe. My advice to young solo female travelers: NEVER visit India alone if you don't know India very well. NEVER go alone unless you stay in very safe places with people you know. When I traveled twice by myself (2014 and 2023) I stayed in ashrams and spiritual communities where I know people, I know are safe places to stay and very peaceful and loving environment. For female travelers go to India only in groups from reputed and well known travel agencies.

comment:
I am an Indian man. While I feel ashamed of Phoebeâ€™s experience, I am not surprised. This is the reason why India, with its vast heritage, ranks very low in tourist turn out. The reason for this phenomenon, as I understand is below:
1. Civility in public life has to be taught in schools and families. The school curriculum does not include it. Those families which do, bring up good citizen, others donâ€™t. 
2. Poor policing and legal support. The administration never focussed on this. 
3. Poor tourist infrastructure. Even localities like Goa which do attract a fair share of tourists does not have facilities that assure to provide fine experience to tourists. 

For anyone who contemplate to visit India ( not sure if anyone who watches this video would), please consider the below:
1. Do not trust shady travel agents. Get connected to someone in India who will help you without commercial motive, say a mutual friend or his contact or someone. 
2. Let them fix up transportation for you, also a known person as guide. 
3. Avoid middle tier hotels. Go for international brands. Home stays for budget travellers only through known connections. 
4. Cities like Mumbai and Bangalore, where you can merge into the crowd will be safe. Same with tourist places which attract better quality Indian tourists.

comment: As a man from India, I am very sorry you went through this experience and I know sorry isn't anything for what you suffered. At the same time, India is a diverse country so there are good places and really really bad places. The usual tourist places like Delhi, Agra and Goa are the worst, these are full of scammers and sexual harassers and even as an Indian man I've never visited any of these places coz to be honest they don't even have anything good to see. comment: I completely understand how you feel and can sense your helplessness. Please let me give you a hug! I have a similar experience to share. In 2018, my two best friends and I traveled to Thailand. The hotel we stayed at had a large pool, and we noticed a group of Indian men, about 8 to 9 of them, who would come downstairs to swim at around 11 AM and again at 4 to 5 PM every day. We were just three young girls, so to avoid them, on the fourth day, we deliberately went downstairs to use the pool at 8:30 AM. But, to our disbelief, just 30 minutes later, we saw these Indian men by the pool's edge (we could clearly see the pool from our room upstairs). It was a very large pool, yet they chose the entrance where we, the three girls, were, on the side, and ignored all the empty sunbeds on the opposite side. They placed their towels on the sunbeds and rocks next to our belongings, effectively surrounding us. The constant feeling of being watched made us very uncomfortable, so we decided to leave the pool. As we were leaving the water and getting out, it was very obvious that every Indian man was staring at us with strange looks, as if they were trying to strip off your swimsuit with their eyes. I assure you, I'm not mistaken about my feelings! When we were changing and leaving the hotel, one of my friends forgot her phone and had to go back. About ten minutes later, she called us to say that three of those Indian men, who should have been swimming, were following her. They came out the side door after us (the side door has a secluded path, but it's the most convenient way to the street). So, we had to abandon the convenient route and go back to the main road where there were more people. Guess what, those Indian men didn't take the side door but followed us to the main entrance instead. After we left the hotel through the main door, we went into a shop not far away and hid for a long time before leaving. Since then, I've had no good impression of Indian men at all! You're lucky that you didn't encounter anything worse; that in itself is a fortunate thing. I hope this won't haunt your life. Reflecting on our experience, we too feel the same sense of relief and gratitude for the luck that was with us.

.

comment: Dear Phoebe! I am one of those solo female travellers who just got back from India. There are rules of solo travelling a Western woman should be aware of: 1. Dress local! preferably cheap and simple to stay invisible. In some places, it's best to cover your hair too! 2. Walk around with confidence, you can smile, joke and talk to people. But do NOT touch or shake hands with anyone as this is perceived as an invite. Namaste (folded hands) is enough. 3. Crowded tourist places - avoid eye contact, be determined and assertive, don't engage. 4. Never arrive at a new place late and/or when it's dark However, I mostly experienced travelling on pilgrimages to spiritual sites, and the crowd there might be a little different. You do get selfy requests though from men, women and sometimes even the whole family! I take it easy and most of the times say yes. One has to understand, that once you set your foot in an Asian country you have to forget what Privacy is. I find Indian people super friendly and kind. Though yes, they can annoy the life out of you! I am so so sorry about the experiences you had :(
counterspeech_english: Don't apologize for your experiences, lady. They're real and valid, unlike your clueless advice. Enjoy your next trip without following your own guidelines. Peace out.

comment: My wife and I do general contracting in the states and took off a winter to take our tools and find an orphanage in India and do labor on the place and love the kids. While traveling looking for the right orphanage we went on a trek to the Triund. (Dharamsala) While trekking the road coming down off the mountain, we heard a loud group of men yelling out of their vehicle. So, I told my wife hide behind me and we luckily found a small crevasse in the rocks to shield her from view. One guy in the van got a glimpse of her and yelled," BLONDIE!!!" The van slide to a stop and all these guys started jumping out. All drunk and higher than a kite. I am 6' 2" 190 pounds and have done hard labor my whole life, barley any fat on my body. My thought was telling them we have been married for 30 years. My wife looks like she is 30. IF that didn't work, I had one option the first drunk guy reaching towards her goes 500 feet down off the cliff. It was a terrible dilemma Thank God another car came beeping their horn and they had to move their van down the hill. We exited the road went bush and luckily found our way down off the mountain. But low and behold they were waiting in the van at the end of the road. Luckily, we saw them and avoided them. The kids at the orphanage were GREAT! However, 2 months in we witnessed the smallest child have his head smashed hitting the back of his head into his food plate twice, for not eating and he was sick with the flu. We contacted the Vice Chairman at the time of the Bal Ashram Orphanage in Saliana and he said no kids are hit there. Went over his head to the Chairman an MD and he said the same thing, went to the editor of the local paper he said he would run a front-page story, and he said I wish you would have come to me I would tell you never go there they are thefts of donated money. Well, nothing happened, no story. So got on an overnight bus and traveled to see the S.P. , like our Attorney General. He sent his man in the Chief of Police at Saliana and no one talked. The cook said all the kids had been singled out and had the heck scared out of them if they talked. A couple of years later thank God the chief of Police's daughter said they got them out of there. The Chief and his family ware great people. BTW we were thrown out of the orphanage by a group of big guys into the darkness in the middle of the night onto an unlit street. An Indian guy we met let us stay at his house and two nights later the entry doorknob was turning, and we had it locked luckily. Guns are illegal in India, and he had given me a shotgun to defend my wife. If I would have killed some guys I would of went to jail there. We are NOT going back to India two winters from now doing philanthropy in Nepal, which has a good reputation for tourists. BEWARE OF INDIA a VERY VERY SMALL PORTION OF MEN THAT WANT TO SET UP A SITUATION WHICH "THEY BELIEVE CONDONES" A WOMEN ALEGELY ASKING FOR A GANG RAPE AND WE WERE SOMETIMES TREATED LIKE WE WERE A WALKING ATM MACHINE! However, we met many very spiritual people there and my own spirituality is now eastern it's just a shame that a few bad apples can be so dangerous to western women especially. I would not be afraid to travel there as a man by myself. Here is a short film about it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WRVLVrWfCMo&t=32s
counterspeech_english: Wow, sounds like you had quite the adventure and learned a lot about human nature. Glad you're safe now, but that situation with the kids at the orphanage was truly horrifying. Good call on

comment: I spent 5 months travelling in India 20 years ago (Australian male) and met some solo female travellers who all seemed to have some bad stories. I can confirm that the south of India was my favourite and so much less frantic than the north. In the north there always seems to be someone in your face. Unfortunately it seems the only safe way for a female to travel there is with a male partner or friend. Even as a solo male I had some times where I had to be very vigilant and on guard. Not saying it is normal, but anytime you go to a place of abject poverty or isolation, you should expect people's values to be different. A white woman with long locks like yours makes you stand out even more.

comment:
Actually, you can get a glimpse of what India is about also as a male. The level of harrasement, begging, nagging etc. is strong, the amount of selfies requested or the somehow loaded question "how do you like india" (be very careful what you say there, anyhting from outright praises will draw unwanted attention). You have to be constant on alert, everybody approaching you is trying to scam you. There where days, where you had to defend yourself against scams 10 hours a day, after the first one stopped the next one is starting. You are learning to be firm and rude otherwise you really run into problems. Might be that I did do injustice here also for some friendly Indians, but if you leave your guard down your are done. 
But your video is quite an eye opener what it means if you are travelling as a female plannign travelling to India. Your whole tour sounds like an absolute nightmare but sadly I can say: I am not very much suprised. Look by the way in the videos of other travelers,- there are reasons why you do not see much or any woman at all in the streets alone. 
Haven said that, there are also very good people in India, especially the private hosts which can make your trip way more enjoyable. In general I really could not recommend visiting India as a solo female.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, so now I'm supposed to feel better knowing that harassment is just a normal part of life in India. Thanks for the pep talk. Glad to know being rude makes everything better. Let

comment: I wouldn't recommend anyone visiting India alone for the first time. I've visited many countries and can strongly say India is a lot different from them because things don't go by the book here. Only people who have been living here since many years can help you avoid these scams and experience the good part of India. But finding the right person who can genuinely help you and show you around is so hard. I wouldn't recommend travel packages also as their primary objective is to earn money. Only case in which I would suggest a foreigner to visit India is if you have a close Indian friend whom you met somewhere in your university or at work and is willing to show you around.

comment:
I hope people don't consider "Please don't visit India, it is dangerous for women" like comments seriously, those types of messages are wrong to learn.

Instead we have 2 things to learn -
- India has a social problem of women harassment. India, and it's miscreants need to work on that, but this is a long term goal. The social fabric will not change overnight.
- Meanwhile, visitors should "Do proper research, know what to expect, and be prepared". These are factors that people can control themselves. If they do this, they can expect a far more welcoming and enjoyable experience and you will discover good side of India

comment: This is a shame. I was looking at your solo India videos, but it feels tainted now.  As someone from India: I'm sorry you had that experience, but you aren't the only one. To be frank, if any white woman asked me if it was okay to travel alone today in India, I would say no.  It can be safe, but it requires lots of research and contact with locals who have helped people who've been on that journey before, and it seems like you were unable to find the right people to make you feel comfortable consistently. That's the way it is at the moment, sadly. Wish you had received better advice before embarking on the trip.
counterspeech_english: Sorry to hear you feel that way. Glad you're being honest though, at least now I know what not to do. Solo trips are for the weak anyway. Good luck getting home safely. Cheers

comment:
Extremely disappointed for your experience. No one should be facing these situations.

Lesson other people SHOULD learn - Control factors, which they can control before visiting any unknown country to make sure they are able to absorb new cultures while minimizing chances of having a spoiled experience -

"Do proper research, know what to expect, and be prepared"

There can be many idiosyncrasies in how countries can be welcoming or unwelcoming at the same time.

For India, many visitors, including solo visitors too, have great experiences while traveling and interacting with locals, even when using public transport. It is "knowledge" / "skill" - to know what areas or activities can be safe, and where to expect the goons or scammers.

All this to say, I am definitely not writing your experience off and fully empathize. What people did with you is criminal and I hope you are able to overcome this. At the same time, for people who want to visit India, they are still fully welcome!

(Having a local friend to give some pro tips definitely helps, as locals are more aware when to be more aware, and always always always be CONFIDENT AND ASSERTIVE against scammers)

Good luck
