comment: So sad this happened to you!. I'm an American woman but of Indian descent and it's been years since I've been to India. I love the country and moreover the culture,, and as a someone who looks clearly Indian and speaks Hindi, I of course haven't had the same experience that white people or people of other cultures have had. That being said, growing up outside of India, I was shocked especially traveling there the last two times as an adult by how many men are on the street/public places in comparison to women.....that alone can feel disconcerting and make a woman feel unsafe. I mainly stay with family in UP, but I would highly encourage any female traveler going alone to India to stay with family or friends or be part of part a legitimate tour group of tourists of a significant number (10-20 people at least). I've heard Mumbai and Bangalore are pretty safe for women, but everywhere else not so much. I was thinking of visiting my family after five years there, but after the recent Kolkata rape case, I feel on edge.....they really need to make rape and even sexual harassment punishable by castration or something, otherwise these gross men will NEVER learn their lesson. A lot of cultures are patriarchal, but I've heard time and again that women feel most unsafe in India even compared to other countries where women don't even have full rights or the same "freedoms." I know Indians feel the country is developing and want the West to appreciate them as well as the beautiful history, culture, music, diversity of religions, etc, but the truth is NOBODY really cares....if women tourists can't even feel safe, of course people are going to just associate the country with gang rapes, sexual harrassment, and acid attacks. Not trying to blame all Indians, but I want my country (yes, even though I'm American I do consider India my country too) to do better, so people can appreciate all the wonderful things about it. But everyone (men, women, and even NRIs) have to put in the work and speak out about this, change behaviors at home, and for god sakes defend women when this is happening to them (unlike those dumb guards and tourists, who did nothing to help Pheobe). Sorry, I wrote too much, but this whole mentality and patter of men (who are sexually frustrated or probably closeted homosexuals) traveling in packs to harass, grope, or even gang rape foreign and/or local women is nauseating and must stop!
counterspeech_english: Oh great, another victim-blaming rant. If you're so concerned about your safety, maybe you should stop traveling to places where you don't belong and stick to your nice little bubble of America.

comment: It is so horrifying to hear that you went through such a traumatic time in India. comment:
I'm an Indian man who has lived in the US for 41 years. US is now my home. I'm outraged that you had to go through these experiences in India. Around the middle of the video, you made a point: You had a lot of bad experiences in India, that doesn't mean that all Indians are bad. I really like that. And that's the truth. Another example: there is a lot of crime in the US but you can't say that all Americans are criminals. My family and I just returned from India after a stay of more than 6 weeks. For two days, we stayed in an upscale hotel in Delhi. When we stepped out to get breakfast and tried to hail an autorickshaw to go to our favorite restaurant, a man approached us and told us that there a was great place (Handloom of India) near our restaurant and that the autorikshaw driver would be happy to take us after our meal there without extra charge. The driver said that was correct. The man also said that there were multiple stores near Handloom where we can shop. Excited, we agreed. We ate our breakfast and headed over to the Handloom. Alas, that was the only store there. We got in nonetheless thinking that we would look at some clothes. An hour and half later, we got out of there having spent 45,000 rupees on things that we didn't even want to buy in the first place. The autorikshaw driver was waiting patiently. He drove us back to our hotel. Right then we realized we got duped big time. The salespeople at the Handloom were aggressive and didn't take a no for an answer. My advice to non-Indians who travel to India:

If possible, don't travel alone. If you do, make sure that you don't stay in shady, cheap places. Spend at least $80 - $100 a night on hotels. Always shop at reputable stores. I don't know what to say about the harassment. Just walk away. Don't make eye contact. Indian men can be brutes. Some of them have no sense of personal space or common courtesy. But I would not lump everyone in the same box. Like you said, there are noble, decent, honorable men in India. Most Indian men are that way, in my opinion. That doesn't mean anything, though, for a tourist like you. Sorry.

Lastly, scammers exist everywhere. They come in different sizes and colors and styles.
counterspeech_english: Oh wow, nice one. Your trip sounds like it went from bad to worse, especially when the rickshaw driver took you to a scam outfit. Glad you're so woke and learned your lesson

comment:
I am sorry about your experience in India.

The issue that ive noticed in most of these experiences is foreigners usually travel to Delhi, Agra, Jaipur and stuff places where even Indians wouldn't want to go.

All those places are hot, dusty, polluted, filthy, and bad overall.

Please if any foreigner plans to visit India go to the mountains in the north (other than kashmir)

The places being - Rishikesh, Nanital, Manali, Shimla, Dharamshala, kasol, uttraknand, kheer ganga, tosh, jhibi and others. ( In the hills the temperature is cool, and the native people over there are hospitable, they know how to respecting tourists and make them feel comfortable)

If you wanna go to the beaches go to Goa, lakshwadeep, andaman nicobar (temperatures are warmer, can be some incidences of harassment sadly)

In south india i can recommend kodaikanal, gokarna, pondicherry 

But please just avoid Delhi and the areas around it, Do not go to Agra please.

Lastly, please if you plan to visit india go to the northeast, they have the best, cutest and friendliest people over there with the best rivers mountains and the best weather.

Avoid Delhi and arears around its a cancer to the Soviety.

comment:
It's really a class based thing. Don't go for tourist agency trying to cut corners and offering low priced packages. Always check out the review with negative sorted first. Given the bad exp you mention regarding Goa, it seems like the tour agency was sending you to the lower middle class/non mainstream accommodations and hang out spots to save money. The way it works is that those spots would be unsafe for most middle & upper class Indians themselves. It takes a lot of local experience to get a hang of this so please don't blame yourself. 

Traveling alone in India is not safe for Indians themselves (solo western women makes it 10-20x more scarier) if you're not able to sense out the different type of Indians you'll be encountering and the correct way to handle it. North India places also differ by city and even then, they're a total challenge if you venture into the low economic areas, which is where most of the times historical monuments are. The population density itself enabled the worst dregs to gravitate towards you while the more decent public won't be anywhere to found because they themselves are avoiding the same. It's such a big country with very high density & heavy inter-state migration, so you need to fight for you personal space in subtle ways. 

Please always go for more mainstream options when it comes to traveling to India or booking an agency.   

Hope you give it another a chance and have a better experience next time o/

comment:
As an Indian (Man) from the southern state called Karnataka. 

I shall apologise on behalf of my nation for your bad experience.
Here is my true thoughts to share about my country (Pros and Cons and tips for better experience):

India is a great country like every other but as you shared the experience, there are dangerous areas and the thought of our people are still at a stage where it may be normal for us but for you is a threat.

Yes, the experience you had is unfortunately quite normal even to us Indians, though the scale of scam is definitely increased for foreigners.

And people like to take photos with a foreigner as there is this false prestige & pride developed due to social media.

We are a developing nation and it will take a lot more time for such mindset to change. And i can assure you. Change is happening. 

If you wish to travel and part of India, book through proper guide and make sure to spend money on a good tour package (India is cheap in terms of price but you will get quality as you spend more.) If traveling alone then plan ahead and plan accordingly (always be prepared for problems and take step by step action).

India is a safe country as long as you stay in areas where we Indians stay and not venture into unsafe areas we do not go.

Know that police is not 911 and emergency no. Varies from area to area. So keep a note.

Find a local Indian who you can trust online. We Indians will help always so reach out to us. 

There are many Indians like me who would help you have a comfortable stay and travel in each and every town. So dont be shy to reach us.

Avoid tourist trap areas. Delhi-Agra-Jaipur are beautiful places but have become tourist traps even to us Locals.

Have the following mindset â­ï¸â­ï¸(most important)

1) Say â€œNOâ€ STRONGLY. People will always wanna sell you and ask photos just say NO in a string voice and a few times.

2) Plan and do not alter from your plans unless avoidable. 

3) Bargain Bargain & Bargain. Its a must needed skill (if cant find a trustworthy local to help you with.) 

4) Everything has a tag called MRP which is the maximum price to sell stuff. If you buy something without MRP its either not mainstream, orginal or home made. So buy stuff with MRP (clothes, accessories and everything has MRP even food.)

5) Food is clean everywhere. But have medication as even we Indians get food poisoned in US/Europe or elsewhere due to change in food.


In summary, India is a safe country as long as you stay Strong, Plan and have a local for support.

(You guys can reach out to me for more questions and suggestions. I dont care if the questions are offensive as long as you wish to learn.)
counterspeech_english: Wow, thanks for the heartfelt speech. Now I know exactly what kind of trouble I'm in. Good luck with that trip. I'll probably just stick to the tourist traps now. Cheers to more

comment:
High pressure sales is something you really have to watch out for on package tours. 

I found this out the hard way. I recently went on holiday to Cairo and some spots down the Nile. Like in this video, it was a package tour with flights, accommodation, transfers and activities sorted. One of my complaints before we left was that the itinerary was quite vague, often saying something like "explore the great pyramid before doing some cultural activities in Cairo". It turns out that "cultural activities" means that you will be taken to various shops and pressured into buying their products. It was really disappointing as 1) the reason we booked the package tour was to avoid these situations and 2) I thought we were going to be diving into the history and culture of Egypt. Instead it seemed to be an opportunity for our guide to have a break, while we were forced around a shop, shadowed by a salesman. These salesmen would use a lot of cheap tricks, for example if you stopped to look at something, they would put it behind the counter, "saving it for you", to pressure you into a purchase. They would not make the prices clear, especially for single items, often using the excuse that "they would come up with a price for ALL the items we were going to pick out, once we had finished shopping". And that was in proper shops. That's before we talk about the gauntlet of street salesmen that you were forced to walk through, coming into and out of attractions. 

I was "lucky" enough to experience this as part of a group tour, so at least the high pressure sales were spread over a group of people. I can only imagine what it was like as a solo traveller. Thank you Phoebe for bringing these practices to light!
counterspeech_english: You're welcome? Seriously though, glad I didn't waste my money on this nonsense. Next time I'll just do my own research and book things independently. Can't trust anyone to give me a

comment:
Phoebe, you could sue, if you can or atleast strongly legal action. 

Im a woman from India. I spent many years outside the country and returned to India during the pandemic and was locked down there. 

What you described about cards not working and leaving hotel room doors unlocked etc is bang on. Female staff in the hostel I stayed in Jaipur walked in on me using the universal key card. Once I did leave the country I couldnt trust for a long time that noone would enter my apartment. 

My family had a family gathering in a star hotel in Bangalore, and the hotel driver who drove me to the airport asked me if my father was a customer of mine and if i was using the cover of "father". We threatened to sue. The star hotel checked our passports and found we were indeed father and daughter and apologized - but it was horrific for us. The front desk staff at the hotel sobbed when she heard me sobbing.
I had a panic attack on the airplane and asked to remove covid masks and was moved inside the airplane and the airhostesses teared up.

The system is systemically exploitative and extractive. 

I had a travel insurance provider who was selling me travel insurance inform me there was no cover for sexually transmitted diseases after asking me if i traveled alone. He had to find a way to patronize me while selling me a product. 

I was asked to cook by a hotel owner and to serve him water during the peak of the pandemic. I was trapped with them and they took the opportunity to humble me. 
I was paying full price at his hotel where he had no other guests because of the pandemic. Im a woman with a very respectable financial standing and this was very jarring experience. Since they controlled food during the pandemic if i didnt pander to their expectations, they would not give me food. I remember being willing to tip people generously just to stop hassling me. I had to pay the price for being a woman that had a level of financial affluence without paying the toll for violating their social norms. 

The government official who administered my vaccine misbehaved with me. I could do nothing without having an instance of SH and it affected me to my very core. There's this dull feeling of resignation when the body goes into survival mode when this happens over and over.

I had a landlord in one of those apartments who was my protector. He made some passes, but very respectfully and told me as I left that I should never return without a male figure. I thanked him because he had looked out for me. 

It was an 8 month long nightmare. My family had left the country but I had an Indian passport and couldnt leave with much ease. I also lost emotional strength and faculties during that stressful phase. 

You made an effort not to hurt people's sentiments while being in excruciating pain yourself. I appreciate it but that takes a heavy emotional toll. Truth is, that is a culture which coddles its men. There should be economic consequences, these are natural consequences.

I eventually purchased a Privilege visa and guaranteed that I would always have another option I could reliably fall back on if there were yet another unforeseen crisis. 
I remember thinking to myself, well death is inevitable but id like to age and pass in a society where I do not feel such an intense alienation towards, not to mention feeling hunted, intruded upon and watched. It has definitely impacted how I relate with men, both from my culture and others.

In Himachal Pradesh, they would matter of fact open my Amazon packages and refuse to pick up my garbage. 

What you said about the sense of relief when you left resonated. I had to sleep for four months and could hardly work, so I requested time off and my clients understood. It took me 14 months to stop being worried that someone would enter my apartment in the next country I now live in. When i shared my concerns in this new country, people are simply amazed that I would even have such a concern. 

Ive been reflecting on my sense of identity, belonging and self worth as it pertains to the country I was born in. 
I question if unconditional loyalty is owed to any system one may belong to where one had no choice. I will change my passport for cathartic reasons. I also plan to lobby for extending refugee visas for Indian minority women so more women who want to live peaceful lives outside can have options availavle to them.

It is an incredible country with a powerful past but I should not have to carry such a heavy weight to accommodate a society I find harder and harder to understand. That the burden should be on you, or on me to communicate effectively while being traumatized and violated is a tad bit excessive.
counterspeech_english: Sorry, but your rant sounds like you're blaming everything on men and the system. Maybe it's time to move on and find happiness somewhere else. Sounds like you've got PTSD. Good luck with

comment:
Phoebe so sorry to hear about this. I am an Indian man and it hurts me to hear that women are being treated like this.

A tip to solo women travelling to India:

It is better to avoid the locations which are famous with local tourists, Jaipur, Agra, Goa. These cities are very very famous with locals. Now these local tourists might be travelling for the first time in their life. They might have never seen any foreigners and they might find you fascinating and would want to click pictures with you. 

To avoid this situation, go to tourist hubs which gets the civilised crowd, the crowd which is well travelled.


Offbeat locations are much better for tourists, because they get the civilised Indian crowd. So instead of Goa maybe you can go to Gokarna, instead of Jaipur you can go to Udaipur or Jodhpur, instead of Haridwar go to Rishikesh. The lesser the number of local tourists the better the experience is going to be.

If you do visit local tourist hub. Try to find areas which are famous with foreigners and stay there. You can ask on any forum. In Goa you have Arambol famous with foreigners.

Again as an Indian man I am sorry for this experience. This fetish of locals for foreign women should be penalised. It is killing it for our guests. The government should run ad campaigns and make the locals understand how it feels to shove cameras into touristsâ€™ faces.

comment:
Hey Phoebe, sorry to hear about your experience in India. As an Indian that grew up in the US, I would make some suggestions. 

Is traveling solo as a female safe in India? Yes & No. You have to do it the right way. Spend the extra money and stay in a proper five star hotel, Oberoi, Taj, Leela, ITC etc. Then book a proper guide through the hotel that they regularly use, not some local. This way, you can tell the guide exactly what you want and what you want to avoid, and they will follow your instructions to the letter. 

Last thing, In India, you have to be rude to a certain extent. You have to keep blinders on and keep walking, pretend you didnâ€™t hear anything when someone asks you a question. In most places in india, do not go out after dusk unless you have truatworthy company. Probably Pune and Mumbai are the only places where you can roam about safely in the dark hours. But still be safe and avoid lonely places with a bad vibe everywhere, be it mumbai, delhi, pune, newyork, london etc, irrespective the city/country. comment:
@travelforphoebe Hai Love, I am really sorry about things which you had to go through. I would like to shed some light and give some pointers to other solo travellers. 

See India is a beautiful place, the tradition, the customs etc but travellers have to understand that this is a country which is still recovering from the shackles of independence, People didn't had much experience to see outside world, for them you are standing out like a Alien or a Deer in headlight. 

If you are vary of people or are a introvert India is not for you. There arw 140 billion people living there.

Now what happens is Most of tourist fall for the Golden triangle trap, they land in Delhi (worst city safety wise even for locals) then there are scammers on every street there because everyone is hustling. Try to spend minimum time there, there is nothing to see much in Delhi. 

Then they go to other tourist trap of Jaipur etc where most of population is not literate. Men and women both are struggling to make ends meet, they have not seen outside world much, so when girls come and visit they get curious. 

Now the mentality of those 95 percent men is not to harm you but to take picture with you to show to their friends or family that they have taken a picture with a white person, it doesn't matter if you are a white male or female they will take pictures with both. 

If you are not comfortable you have to be assertive, it is always advisable to visit some posh places or make some friends prior to visiting india as india is not for beginners. 

Now the most important mistake people do is they just read about these places and go and ignore the best places which they ahould have went like Leh Ladakh, Himachal, Northeast Assam, sikkim, Shimla, j&k, Kerala. The people you will find in these places are more friendly and well accustomed. 

You ahould always book a reputed company for tours and travels, something high end, they take care of all your safety and experience. 

Traveling in india is a experience and it can be Bad or good depending upon how we make it. 

It is always advisable if you are visiting India be prepared to be looked upon, people will approach you out of curiosity, many times 95 percent as I mention they would like to click pictures, aomw might even enjoy the attention and some will not. 

You have to be assertive and maintain distance, always keep a driver accompanied with you if you are alone. 

Even indian people from other cities face same problem, always vary of scams and those trying to take you to shops to buy things. There is a fixed percentage of sales tied. Hence try to avoid such guides and book guides from online well reputed company, they will take care of you. 

I am again sorry for things you had to go through and hope you dont think bad of all Indians and possibly will come back and see other side of india.

India itself is a experience, you just have to find it, as a solo girl traveller it is hard to travel but have to pick the right experience. Avoid scam places. 

Goa is also now full of foreigners, many practically living there, people are SA there but the police is equally stringent there, you can just file a complain and they take care of things. Catcalling and stuff can happen visiting many places even in West, happens to my friends travelling in London. So no place is safer for solo women travellers, you just have to take self precautions and rely more on your inner instincts. 

I would suggest people who are looking to travel to india is look beyond the tourist trap, go for places mentioned above in my comment and see the difference. 

Also those places are natural and clean and serene. Hope it helps clear few things. ğŸ˜Š

If anyone has any questions or need help please write below and I will try to guide properly.

comment:
That is how many Indian men in India are and unfortunately reflects on the culture .. a total shame! not too uncommon for Indian women to experience similar, though things get more out of control when a beautiful white girl or boy walks their neighborhoods.. obsession with white people is still something crazy there. While I'm not from India, I've visited South India and people tell me that its relatively better / safer there - less harassment. The thing you noticed about Indians having a 'pack mentality' is quite common.. when one attacks someone, the rest jump in and join.

A few things I've learned while visiting India - 

1) Always better to travel in a group
2) Stay in mid-top tier hotels - they often have better security, and are faster and better when responding to your needs
3) When traveling in trains, choose first class, or better.. do not travel in a lower class.
4) Taking a rickshaw is fine in places where traffic is very light, like in rural areas. But in cities where traffic is dense, take taxi / cab / Uber / etc.. this goes back to your safety.. plus you will inhale less toxic fumes.
5) Be careful of ALL 'holy men/women'.. many are scammers or simply just out to get money or sex from those they prey upon... in the name of God. 

The big question is, what will President Modi do in his third term to protect tourists? Unfortunately, till today India is referred to as the 'rape capital' of the world.. by foreigners / outsiders.. there's a reason for that. Foreigners should generally feel safe traveling anywhere in India without being harassed or feeling unsafe.

comment:
Really sad to hear this unpleasant and terrible experience. But it's not an anomaly unfortunately.  Hope you recover well from the trip. 

My experiences as a native Indian: (note: The average north indian is the most hospitable person you can get and are really friendly and helpful. So not dissing the average person. I may not be the most adventurous person)

The rest of India is simply more calm and far less overwhelming than the North. The cities are less populated than the north. The ppl are a lot less aggressive and pushy. The scams are lesser than the north (not zero. There's a lot here too. Just lesser). This is something my north indian peers say too. 

Our family's personal experience in Rajasthan: 
We stayed at reputed 4 star hotels throughout the trip. The staff at the hotels were very good. The forts are epic. The Udaipur cruise was awesome. The Rajasthani food is good. 

The problems: We Indians know the art of bargaining and knowing when to spot scams like Pashmina etc etc. We know that tourism guys like cab drivers can be pushy. But even for us it was getting overwhelming. 

We hired a driver via the hotel from Jodhpur to Jaipur. He was nice at first, but highly aggressive later. He wasn't listening to our parents request to drive calmly. His conduct at petrol stations was shady as heck. We were relieved when we reached Jaipur. The agency associated with the Jodhpur hotel that gave the driver apologized and gave us other drivers for Jaipur. The hotel was wonderful. But the first Jaipur driver was highly pushy. He wasn't wanting us to go to Bapu Bazaar which is a beautiful Bazaar. He was pushing us to go to a mall which we weren't interested. We had to be assertive. 

The 2nd driver wasn't pushy but he was unfriendly. 

At Udaipur, the drivers were quite aggressive. This sullied our trip there a bit. It gave a bitter taste. The mistake we made: hiring drivers at the airport in Udaipur, and continuing with the agency from Jodhpur. 

My tips when visiting India: 

Stay at reputed hotel chains like Taj, Ibis, Fortune etc. Don't go to unknown hotels. 

Use guides/drivers from the hotels. Don't use unknown agencies. Even though they maybe more expensive, it helps

Do thorough research. Put your foot down when the driver doesn't want to take you to places you want to visit. Don't let the drivers  dictate how the trip should go. Inform the hotels if you feel uncomfortable. 

Don't fall for scams. If you want to do shopping, shop at places you've researched and feel comfortable. 

Don't indulge in too many conversations outside of the travel related stuff. It can easily get dicey. 

Don't allow auto/cab guys to bring others into the vehicle. 

Be vigilant throughout the journey. Observe the drivers conduct. Walk out if unsafe after pending money settlements. 

Keep cash. It helps. Also keep food poisoning medicines ready.
counterspeech_english: Oh great, so now you're an expert on Indian hospitality. Well done for noticing all these "problems" while everyone else just had a good time. Next you'll tell me to only eat at
